comments.commentBody: For the record, mental illness and domestic violence are two different things. They can co-occur, but they have different roots. Violence towards women is a learned behavior, based on an entitlement belief system in which the perpetrator justifies using any and all means to take from women anything he wants. Violent men believe they are  entitled to possess and control women, do not care about women's rights to mutuality and freedom of choice, and rarely take genuine responsibility for the harms they cause their partners.

Paul:

Agreed w/ you about the matter covered by the other blog subject but have to disagree about spending more money on free agents. The Mets have done that over and over and over again since the early 00's and it really hasn't worked out that well, has it?

All fans want to see their team buy the best free agent players in the off-season and be contenders next year. But it doesn't work unless you've got the cash flow to buy every one of the necessary players or you've got just about all the other players in place already. For the Mets, the situation is exacerbated by the Wilpon's financial troubles and the massive financial obligations that come with the new stadium. Consequently, the Mets only real choice is to rebuild the team on the budget they have.

Under Alderson, the Mets are finally adopting a rebuilding strategy and trading R.A. Dickey was a major part of it. The Mets grasped the fact that if they kept Dickey they'd likely have a winning pitcher for a few seasons but without much of an increased chance of having a winning team.

Accordingly, the Mets decided to trade Dickey at peak market value for a set of prospects who can provide a decade or more of talented play in some of the most important positions the Mets need help with. It was a disappointment to those of us who love R.A., but it was a no-brainer from a med to long term managerial perspective. Even if it doesn't work out at all, the Dickey trade was a chance the Mets absolutely had to take.

Boehner got it because nobody else in the House GOP wanted to be the front man. Everybody understands that the Tea Party caucus in the House is out of control and can't be counted on for anything other than more rage.

The Lincoln Cooper Union speech comes to mind:

"Your purpose, then, plainly stated, is that you will destroy the Government, unless you be allowed to construe and enforce the Constitution as you please, on all points in dispute between you and us. You will rule or ruin in all events."

Describes the Tea Party caucus in the House pretty well. Who would want to try to deal with them? The House GOP is lucky John Boehner didn't just step down and say screw it. God only knows who they would have wound up with otherwise.

Here's hoping the Tea Party continues to make GOP soul-searching a public, fruitless, time-consuming, and expensive process, so the country can eventually excise right wing extremism from positions of political power.

I'd agree that the only way Boehner can accomplish anything is to stop trying to be the Speaker of the House Republicans and be the Speaker of the House, relying on a coalition of both parties to support him and pass legislation.  Douthat assumes he'll never do that, just continue to act as the leader of one party in the House and try to get that party to agree to "can-kicking" deals that postpone problems and solve nothing.

Please let me suggest you change the type of bathtub. It is not proverbial and your comment would have been even more wonderful if you had said, "...to drown the federal government in Norquist's bathtub."

I agree that Mr. Boehner has an extraordinarily difficult job for all the reasons you give. I am not sure he has been successful. If he really had the interests of the country first and foremost in mind, he would remind himself daily that he is The Speaker of the House, that includes both Republicans and Democrats. He needs to think through exactly what agenda he wants and then find a coalition from both sides. He needs to give up on herding his cats.

My sense of his failure comes from the fact that he doesn't have specific legislative goals. Why doesn't he put together a very specific tax reform proposal and then submit it to the House for a vote? His strategy so far is to give very general proposals, such as cutting deductions, without being specific. I think this is in large part because the GOP itself can't agree on what deductions to cut. Since he lacks the will to draft legislation himself, he demands the President come up with legislation. Well, that isn't the President's job. It is Mr. Boehner's. And now we get hints that he is going to leave it to the Senate to write legislation.

I want him to succeed at his job. We need a House that is functional. It never will be functional if Mr. Boehner kowtow's to the most extreme in his party who came to Washington to drown the federal government in the proverbial bathtub.

Try checking out the Center for Science in the Public Interest on the web.
"Michael Jackson did Pepsi ads."  And what did he get for it?  His hair caught fire!  LOL (sort of...)  Seriously, I was surprised that Mark didn't mention MJ.

Celebrities sell a lot more overseas than they do domestically. Since the start of the recession, we've seen an increase in celebrity advertising. I guess it's a sign of the times. Michael Jackson did Pepsi ads. Now it's Beyonce. It used to be that olympians did Wheaties commercials right after the Olympics. Now, everyone is selling something on the TeeVee.

We need to push for better food in the schools and real nutrition education, starting in primary school. We need better public education about nutrition and what it is that's added to what we eat, when we buy ready-made or processed foods, and when we eat out. We need to teach how to tell quality food from junk. Junk food isn't only candy or chips, it's as much what you see in the frozen section as what you are served in fast-food places or at large family restaurant chains. Ask for a food label at Marie Callender's and compare it to a Stouffer's frozen meal and you won't find much of a difference.

I'd love to see a survey of what doctors consider good food, and what specific types of foods (brands included) they would deem ok for their patients with diabetes, for example.

We have a very long road ahead of us when it comes to knowing how to eat right.

To Charley James:

The issue isn't whether we should go back to "a completely free market". Very few people, including Republicans, believe that - and there's a difference between conservatism and libertarianism. There's a continuum between unfettered free markets and state-controlled economies. The real issue is where on that continuum we should be. Reasonable people can disagree on that question. There are one heck of a lot of Republicans who believe in regulated capitalism, but who oppose heavy-handed regulation designed to assuage ideological purity rather than meet practical ends. And no, that doesn’t mean we oppose clean air and water, or untested drugs.

"What we had were unregulated businesses causing great harm to everyone but their owners, sweat shops complete with child labor, and people starving on the streets even as the 1% built great fortunes"

Charley James, by what mechanism did unregulated businesses cause sweatshops, child labor and people starving on the streets?

To be considered a science a discipline has to be testable, quantifiable, and predictable.

How would you test a component of economics? The best we could do, is look at the history of economic activity and see if the particular actions at the time followed the predictions of those who instituted it.

For instance how could we test the Libertarian-neo-classical theory of a completely free market? Do we have any examples of such to show just how it actually worked? It may have been possible in some ancient time when societies were separated by distance and travel was by slow equines.

However, today with almost all countries interacting there is no way to isolate any one program from another. We do have examples of failures such as North Korea and Cuba, but even they seem to be surviving, not that most of us would want to in their manner.

There is the example of the Black-Scholles Model that garnered a Nobel, and proved to be a complete failure when every entity that had those wonderful CDOs suddenly tried to sell them as soon as they lost 7%.

The argument over the stimulus & TARP programs will be fought for years to come. Some will find positive results, and others negative ones. Economics like all other studies is driven by theories. I for one am partial to P.Ks point of view, and he seems to have enough data and rational reasons for me to accept his views.

As for testing them, we have to wait for history to validate them. What looks good today, may crash tomorrow.

Hear, hear, Steve, whoever you are.  Since their inception in 1981, there have been well over 800 MacArthur recipients, and, unquestionably, all were, and in most cases continue be, people deserving of respect and admiration for their achievements.  But 800+ "geniuses"?  In a single generation?  And almost entirely just in the West?  Darwin is rolling over in his grave.

You must remember that people who write articles about authors are rarely, themselves, geiiuses. To a modest intellect the word "genius" often seems applicable. It's really not a big deal and, in the final analysis, just doesn't matter.
These are nice books by a good writer and probably worth your time (when you finish Dickens, Chekov, Dostoyevsky, Shakespeare, Roth, Joyce and a few others).

I wonder if there will ever be a time that the MacArthur prize will stop being referred to as a "genius" award. The organization that awards it never referred to it as that way and if someone reviews most of the winners it is often giving for good works that, while they may be innovative, hardly qualify as works of genius.
Perhaps Mr. Saunders is a genius but I wonder then in what class does one place other writers like Dickens, Chekov, Dostoyevsky, and, of course, Shakespeare. Do we consider them part of a class of "super geniuses?"

This makes me think, OK "deferring" six figures. Like that is the "best" goal, making money doing meaningless gyrations on Wall St. Yet spend time teaching an inner city kid isn't "worth" much.

I have a friend who has an advanced degree in psychology, and did both market research for trivial consumer products while working p/t in a mental health clinic. Having to eventually make a decision, she chose the mental health work with "real" people, at less income. She said she liked the money in marketing, but her day felt much more useless there. In terms of overall life, that made sense to me.

I do not agree with John Boehner's policy positions, but I respect him. At heart, he's on the Hill to work for the people and to find solutions. He works to be faithful to Republican policy, but he is enough of a pragmatist to reach across the aisle when needed and to compromise in order to get legislation passed. In short, he's a responsible adult, unlike many others in his caucus.

I'd be happier if more House Republicans conducted themselves like Boehner. That would produce better likelihood of getting the people's business done, rather than continuing the exhausting dysfunction of the past two years.

Ed...........Your message is clear so why not just say it?

By "celebrity adulation" you are only referring to President Obama. Your attempt to hide behind the other six paragraphs is a cover-up.

How interesting that the party that defined "purity testing" of its members, excludes serious numbers of minorities, and aggressively seeks to legislate womens' health is now decrying how partisan and win-at-all-cost DC has become.

Whose 'up' and whose 'down'...who were the winners and who were the losers in the past week in Washington? It defines the national media as they discuss each week...the happenings in Washington.

Search and dig through the discourse each week, with their panels of so-called experts, and one comes up with the sickening feeling that it is all about the personalties in Washington...the politicians who were elected to serve their constituents back home.

Surely the newcomers, the newly elected, will still have their principles guarded, fresh from election day success. It is the status quo...those that appear on the Sunday talk shows...that get the national attention. It is these people, the hardcore partisans, that live by party-line values.

They are evaluated by these panels of political pundits...and we Americans listen, hanging on every word, looking for some glimmer of hope, some positve sign of optimism.

Yet, what is happening...we are watching certain powerful elected officials in Washington...competing among themselves, locked in their idealogy, completly unaware of the 3oo some million Americans, and the hardships that are looming down the road.

Still, the game is being played every week...the game of winners and losers...talking about President Obama and the so-called loyal opposition. It is the death knell of our democracy, when those that are elected to serve us are being viewed as celebrities...while we look by as spectators.

The game of celebrity adulation.
